company_info.text: Special Service for Groups (SSG) is a non-profit organization dedicated to providing community-based solutions to the social and economic issues facing those in greatest need. In its 66 year history, SSG has evolved into a model organization designed to provide service to diverse groups with maximum efficiency and impact. This is achieved by developing and managing programs that serve our many communities by encouraging their involvement and self-sufficiency. We believe that the needs of groups
highlights: Today, SSG operates over 20 human service divisions that offer a wide scope of services that include: Mental and behavioral health treatment, homeless services, HIV treatment and prevention, occupational therapy, obesity prevention, environmental justice projects and older adult services.

managing programs that serve our many communities by encouraging their involvement and self-sufficiency. We believe that the needs of groups and individuals cross traditional ethnic, racial, and other cultural boundaries. SSG serves as a bridge between people with common needs to identify ways to pool resources for the greater good of all.

sfusd_contract.text:
Citywide Workforce Development Plan
FY 2024-2029

Ohlone Land Acknowledgement
This report was produced on the unceded ancestral homeland of the Ramaytush Ohlone who are the 
original inhabitants of the San Francisco Peninsula. As the indigenous stewards of this land, and in 
accordance with their traditions, the Ramaytush Ohlone have never ceded, lost, nor forgotten their 
responsibilities as the caretakers of this place, as well as for all peoples who reside in their traditional 
territory. As guests, we recognize that we benefit from living and working on their traditional homeland. 
We wish to pay our respects by acknowledging the Ancestors, Elders, and Relatives of the Ramaytush 
Ohlone community and by affirming their sovereign rights as First Peoples.
Commitment to Equity
On behalf o
highlights:
Ohlone community and by affirming their sovereign rights as First Peoples.
Commitment to Equity
On behalf of the Committee on City Workforce Alignment, OEWD collected data and prepared this 
document. 
OEWD advances equitable and shared prosperity for San Franciscans by growing sustainable jobs,

supporting businesses of all sizes, creating great places to live and work, and helping everyone achieve 
economic self-sufficiency. 
To further opportunities for all San Franciscans, we create equitable pathways to good paying jobs, 
addressing challenges to diversity and inclusion in the local job market. We invest in the retention and

stabilization of small businesses, nonprofits, and community organizations, addressing the displacement 
that challenges the civic vitality of San Francisco’s diverse and vibrant neighborhoods. We also lead the 
approval and implementation of significant development projects that create more housing, especially

affordable housing, while maximizing jobs, community benefits, and services. All of these efforts support 
broader social and economic goals that improve the quality of life for our residents. 
OEWD is committed to addressing our responsibility to advance workforce equity through our programs 
and services by changing the beliefs, policies, institutions,

INTENT TO APPLY RESULTS – UPDATED DECEMBER 11, 2025
This document provides the updated results of the Intent to Apply process for the 2025–2026 
Community Grants Request for Proposals (RFP). The Intent to Apply process was used to verify 
applicant compliance with the Minimum Qualifications (MQs) required for this RFP before 
proposals could be submitted. As part of this process, proposers submitted information about 
their proposed program(s) and uploaded documentation to demonstrate compliance with MQs.
DCYF released the initial Intent to Apply results on November 24, 2025. Applicants deemed 
ineligible were able to submit a protest from November 24 through December 1, 2025. All protests 
were re

BOARD MEETING DATE: September 7, 2018 AGENDA NO. 19
REPORT: FY 2017-18 Contract Activity
SYNOPSIS: This report lists the number of contracts let during FY 2017-18, the 
respective dollar amounts, award type, and the authorized contract 
signatory for the SCAQMD. This report includes the data provided 
in the March 2018 report covering contract activity for the first six 
months of FY 2017-18.
COMMITTEE: No Committee Review
RECOMMENDED ACTION:
Receive and file.
Wayne Nastri
Executive Officer
SJ:DH:EA:av
Background
The Board’s Procurement Policy and Procedures requires staff to provide semi-annual 
reports to the Board on contract activity. This report is for the full Fiscal Year and 
includes the data provided in the March 2018 report covering contract activity for the 
first six months of
highlights:

(Board or Executive Officer) is indicated. 
Summary
The total value of all contracts and contract modifications for this period (FY 2017-18) 
was $167,826,163.52, with 255 contracts and contract modifications totaling 
$164,693,627.44 (98%) approved by the Board and 294

in the March 2018 report covering contract activity for the first six 
months of FY 2017-18.
COMMITTEE: No Committee Review
RECOMMENDED ACTION:
Receive and file.
Wayne Nastri
Executive Officer
SJ:DH:EA:av
Background
The Board’s Procurement Policy and Procedures requires staff to provide semi-annual

reports to the Board on contract activity. This report is for the full Fiscal Year and 
includes the data provided in the March 2018 report covering contract activity for the 
first six months of FY 2017-18. The report identifies five categories of contract awards: 
1) New Awards – new contracts for professional services and research projects; 2)

Other – air monitoring station leases, Board Assistant agreements, or miscellaneous 
lease agreements that generate revenue, e.g., lease of SCAQMD space; 3) Sponsorships 
– contracts funding public events and technical conferences which provide air quality 
related benefits; 4) Modifications – amendments to existing contracts usually reflecting

changes in the project scope and/or schedule; 5) Terminated Contracts – Partial/No 
Work Performed – modifications to contracts to reflect termination of a portion or all of
the work which result in de-obligation of contract funding. The report further specifies 
under New Awards, which contracts were awarded competitively and which were

2028; finding that the adopted refuse rates are just and reasonable; affirming the

WHEREAS, In June 2022, the voters adopted Proposition F, which amended the City’s 
Refuse Collection and Disposal Ordinance to reform and modernize the City’s process for 
setting residential refuse rates to be more fair, transparent, and accountable. Among other

PUBLIC NOTICE 
Hunters View Redevelopment Project 
REVISED REVIEW PERIOD ending APRIL 14, 2008 
PLANNING DEPARTMENT CASE NO. 2007.0168E 
STATE CLEARINGHOUSE NO. 2007112086 
This Notice supersedes the Notice dated March 1, 2008 which stated the EIR public review period as 
March 1, 2008 to April 4, 2008. The new public review period is March 1, 2008 to April 14, 2008 (45 
days). Comments will be received until 5:00 p.m. April 14, 2008 and should be addressed to Bill 
Wycko, Acting Environmental Review Officer, San Francisco Planning Department, 1650 Mission 
Street, Suite 400, San Francisco, CA 94103. Comments received at the public hearing and in writing 
will be responded to in a Summary of Comments and Responses document. 
THERE ARE NO CHANGES TO THE PROPOSED PROJECT O
highlights:
View Associates, LP, assisted by the San Francisco Redevelopment Agency and the Mayor’s Office of Housing propose to 
construct up to 800 residential units in multiple buildings. The project would replace one-for-one the existing 267 public 
housing units, and would result in a mixed-income community comprised

properties. The first is at Middle Point and West Point Roads and Wills and Hare Streets, Assessor’s Block 4624, Lots 3, 4 
and 9. The second is along Keith Street, Assessor’s Block 4720, Lot 27. The San Francisco Housing Authority and Hunters

materials are available for review by appointment at the Planning Department's office at 1650 Mission Street, 4th Floor. 
(Call 575-9025) 
Project Description: The 22.5-acre project site, the existing Hunters View Public Housing, is comprised of two adjacent

A Draft Environmental Impact Report (EIR) has been prepared by the San Francisco Planning Department in connection 
with this project. A copy of the report is available for public review and comment at the Planning Department offices at 
1660 Mission Street, 1st Floor Planning Information Counter or on-line at www.sfgov.org/site/planning/mea. Referenced

Street, Suite 400, San Francisco, CA 94103. Comments received at the public hearing and in writing 
will be responded to in a Summary of Comments and Responses document. 
THERE ARE NO CHANGES TO THE PROPOSED PROJECT OR THE ENVIRONMENTAL DOCUMENT.

company_info.title: About – The Richmond Neighborhood Center
company_info.text: Linda Fries, an artist who was raising two small children in the Richmond District at the time, was among the first to recognize the need for a community center. After learning about the plans for the new condo complex, she conducted a needs assessment of the neighborhood and discovered that there were more unmet needs for child care and other neighborhood services than any other district in the city. Residents banded together with Fries, established a non-profit organization, and secured a lo
highlights: Since 1980, the Neighborhood Center has grown into a thriving, multi-purpose community center with programs serving all ages in the neighborhood. Our shared space flourishes with children hard at play at the Cross Cultural Family Center, jazz music piping through the Community Music Center, families seeking an after school program and lively crowds at our
many events. The Richmond Neighborhood Center has truly become a second home for everyone in the community and we hope it will for you, too!

services than any other district in the city. Residents banded together with Fries, established a non-profit organization, and secured a long-term lease from the property owner—the San Francisco Unified School District.

company_info.title: The Richmond Neighborhood Center
company_info.text:
[Skip to content] 

# Dedicated to the Richmond

The Richmond Neighborhood Center is a nonprofit organization dedicated to strengthening the Richmond District and beyond. For 45 years, we have fostered a thriving community through innovative youth programs in 11 public schools, essential food security initiatives, and support for local businesses and neighborhood events. By bringing people together, we create opportunities, build connections, and ensure our community continues to flourish.

[Lea
highlights: The Richmond Neighborhood Center is a vital resource for community connection and support in San Francisco's Richmond District. We partner with schools, families, and local organizations to provide essential programs that empower our neighbors to thrive. From school-based school year and summer enrichment for over 3,000 public school students to food

security services for 1,500 households, our work addresses critical needs with care and dignity. We also host vibrant community events, youth workforce development initiatives, and senior empowerment workshops, all rooted in justice, equity, and sustainability. Together, we’re building a stronger, more connected Richmond.

company_info.title: About Us - Neighborhood Resource Center of Greater Fulton
company_info.text:
# About Us

# NRC MISSION AND OVERVIEW

### Who We Are:

**Our vision:** A thriving, inclusive Greater Fulton.

**![] Our mission:** Neighborhood Resource Center strengthens families. We build relationships, sharing resources, and developing skills to enhance lives in Greater Fulton.

We are an educational and cultural center fostering personal growth and community change in Greater Fulton, an impoverished community in Richmond’s East End. We were formed in March 2002 as a response to the underl
highlights: We are an educational and cultural center fostering personal growth and community change in Greater Fulton, an impoverished community in Richmond’s East End. We were formed in March 2002 as a response to the underlying conditions of low-educational attainment and poverty in the community.

In February 2004, a dedicated group of volunteers purchased the old vacant community post office and, with the help of supporters and friends, transformed the building into a vibrant community center. In January 2005, we officially opened with an after-school tutoring program, GED classes and an early youth literacy program. For more than two decades, we

sfusd_contract.title: SFUSD's Non-School Property Portfolio - SFEDup
sfusd_contract.text:
# [SFEDup] 

SubscribeSign in

# SFUSD's Non-School Property Portfolio

### "One of the stupidest contracts The City has ever entered into", and other stories behind over 30 non-school properties

Dec 17, 2024

7

[2] 
1

[Share] 

In a previous post, we looked at what happens to schools after they close and found that the [most common outcome is that they reopen]. This post is going to focus on all the real property SFUSD owns today that is not being used for schools or child development centers. From shopping centers to offices, and parking lots to open spaces, we’ll look at why SFUSD owns them and what is currently being done with them.

## Who Owns The Schools?

For a long time, it wasn’t clear whether SFUSD even owned its own school buildings. The school district was not legally separ
highlights: titles. In 1983, the Chronicle reported that the City agreed to pay the school district $2.25 million in exchange for clear title to “the Richmond, Taraval, and Potrero police stations, fire engine company number 6 on 12th Avenue, the old juvenile court building on Otis Street, and 13 city parks and playgrounds.” This deal, called a quitclaim agreement, was

For a long time, it wasn’t clear whether SFUSD even owned its own school buildings. The school district was not legally separate from the City and County of San Francisco before 1927. The title to many public properties acquired before 1927 was left in legal limbo after the separation[1]. It has been the off and on work of many decades to clear up the

eventually signed the following year. At the same time, “the city and school district still have not reached a legal agreement on who owns the property on which 84 (sic) of the district’s schools are built[2].”

In a previous post, we looked at what happens to schools after they close and found that the [most common outcome is that they reopen]. This post is going to focus on all the real property SFUSD owns today that is not being used for schools or child development centers. From shopping centers to offices, and parking lots to open spaces, we’ll look at why

Thanks for reading SFEDup! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work.

Subscribe

Acting with all deliberate speed, the school district and city waited 27 years to make further progress. Apparently, under the terms of the 1984 quitclaim, the school district still retained some reversionary interest in the three police stations,

# Youth are the center of our community.
## Community Youth Center of San Francisco champions the diverse youths in our community–giving them a voice in their futures and pathways to success.
highlights:
## Community Youth Center of San Francisco champions the diverse youths in our community–giving them a voice in their futures and pathways to success.
### For more than 55 years, CYC has provided the youth of our city a sense of belonging and vital tools and experiences to succeed in life.

CYC serves more than 8,000 youth each year and is one of only a few agencies in the city addressing the needs of a diverse population of low-income, high-need, and at-risk Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI), Latinx, and African American youth. We believe in opening doors of opportunity based on individual interests and needs, always with multiple

This season, your generosity brings warmth and reassurance to San Francisco youth who count on CYC. When you give to Heart of the Holidays, you help young people find comfort and stability within a community that believes in them. Together, we can make the holidays a little brighter for every child who walks through our doors.
[GIVE TODAY] 
![] 
![]

## [Looking back—and forward] 
Our just-released annual report covers our important accomplishments and memories from the past year, working with youth and families in individual neighborhoods and across San Francisco.
[read more]

## About

Community Youth Center of San Francisco provides the culturally diverse youth of our community a shared sense of belonging, fuel for their curiosities, and a voice in their futures.

Our mission is to encourage a diverse population of high-need young people to explore their full potential through academic, career, family, and community life.

*** PRESS RELEASE ***
COIT TOWER TO WELCOME VISITORS AGAIN
San Francisco, CA — Coit Tower, the iconic white column defining the San Francisco
skyline, will welcome visitors Thursday, June 17 for the first time in 15 months, Mayor
London N. Breed announced today.

Direct: 628.652.7589 | www.sfplanning.org

From: "Press Office, Mayor (MYR)" 
Date: Wednesday, June 16, 2021 at 9:29 AM

Subject: *** PRESS RELEASE *** COIT TOWER TO WELCOME VISITORS AGAIN
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:
Wednesday, June 16, 2021

The 210-foot welcoming beacon, which also houses the largest Depression Era art collection
in the U.S., normally sees up to 1,500 visitors a day. Health orders shuttered the National
Historic Site March 15, 2020.
Coit Tower will resume selling tickets for elevator rides to its observation deck, where

Public Works of Art Project, a precursor to the Works Progress Administration.
Guided tours of the artwork will be limited to six people at one time. Coit Tower’s gift shop
and café kiosk will also re-open Thursday.
“From its panoramic views to the Depression Era frescoes painted on its walls, Coit Tower

sightseers can enjoy 360-degree views of the City and the San Francisco Bay. Masks are
required in the elevator.
Visitors can admire the 26 murals inside the tower’s base for free. The frescoes, which depict
life in California during the Depression, were painted in 1934 by artists employed by the

case management, academic support/advocacy, individual & family therapy, enrichment/field trips

highlights: The San Francisco Unified School District signed a contract with OpenAI three weeks before seeking approval from its school board, authorizing district-wide use of emerging digital tools without the public oversight that usually precedes such decisions.

Posted in[Artificial Intelligence],[Education] # School District Approves OpenAI Contract, Bypassing Board and Raising Student Privacy Concerns
![Avatar photo] by[Sylvie Sturm] February 5, 2026February 5, 2026
### Share this:
* [Share on Bluesky (Opens in new window)Bluesky] 
* [Share on Nextdoor (Opens in new window)Nextdoor]

* ![Stairs lead to the entrance of a concrete building with signs describing it as the San Francisco Unified School District administrative building.] San Francisco Unified School District’s handling of a proposed OpenAI agreement has prompted questions about transparency and governance in school technology decisions.Credit:[Courtesy of Wikimedia Commons CC

The move caused concern among union leaders heading into strike negotiations in which teachers have raised the specter of artificial intelligence threatening jobs. But it was the appearance of a deal being done with little to no discussion over safeguarding student data privacy that most alarmed an organization that monitors use of surveillance technology

peer_districts.title: Annual Contracts over $25000 - CCSD21
peer_districts.text:
# Annual Contracts over $25,000

**Public Reporting on District Contracts**

Below is an excerpt from the Guidance Reporting Requirements on Contracts Exceeding $25,000:

_The School Code was amended in January of 2008 to add requirements concerning reports on contracts exceeding $25,000, beginning with FY 08, in conjunction with submission of the Annual Statement of Affairs (105 ILCS 5/10-17)._

The new provisions, effective for FY 08, include the following requirements:

_A school board must list on the district’s Internet website, if any, all contracts over $25,000 and any contract that the school board enters into with an exclusive bargaining representative._

Compliance with this requirement can be achieved if all contracts exceeding $25,000, including personal service contracts and a
highlights: _A school board must list on the district’s Internet website, if any, all contracts over $25,000 and any contract that the school board enters into with an exclusive bargaining representative._
list.

_The School Code was amended in January of 2008 to add requirements concerning reports on contracts exceeding $25,000, beginning with FY 08, in conjunction with submission of the Annual Statement of Affairs (105 ILCS 5/10-17)._

The new provisions, effective for FY 08, include the following requirements:

Compliance with this requirement can be achieved if all contracts exceeding $25,000, including personal service contracts and agreements with an exclusive bargaining representative, are posted in a list on the district website. Subsequent to the initial posting, as such contracts exceeding $25,000 are awarded by the school board, they should be added to the

Contracts to be excluded from the report submitted to ISBE would include: (1) collective bargaining agreements with district employee groups; and (2) personal services contracts with individual district employees.

company_info.text:
Staffing and Recruiting

San Diego, California 3,242 followers

Education and Healthcare Staffing | Nationwide Travel Jobs ✈️
highlights:
About us

As your trusted and experienced healthcare and education staffing firm, we've got you covered. With top therapy, allied, and nursing professionals in our network, you can find your perfect match with us.

As a San Diego based Staffing Agency, our priority is creating strong relationships between healthcare professionals, clients, and our team so you can secure the best contracts and highest compensation. Our credentialing and compliance team is renowned for being the fastest and most communicative in the industry, simplifying the process from offer to start

For over a decade, we have been specializing in the placement of therapists, teachers, nurses and other professionals in clinical facilities and school districts throughout the United States. Whether you have chosen the path of Special Education, Speech-Language Pathology, Occupational Therapy, Physical therapy, or Nursing we will be there
View all 180 employees
We are dedicated to ensuring that staffing is accessible to everyone, so no student or patient goes without the necessary services due to limited resources or caregivers.

Could I include WCPSS as a reference since I currently 
have an IEE contract? Or would this not count since it's 
already part of WCPSS?
Yes, if in combination with other references.
I could provide references from Preschool directors and 
Private school directors that I currently work with? They 
are not contract based but I do partner with SEVERAL 
community preschools and private schools.
These references are acceptable if provided in combination 
with other, contract-based references.

“Pollution Liability” apply to this contract?

highlights:

depending on need.
Background and Project 
Objectives/Scope of Work (pg. 5)
What is the anticipated number of full time and part 
time positions?
The staffing needs depends on the number of 
vacancies. Here is an estimated projection:
PT: 1
SLP: 20
OT: 8

“Pollution Liability” apply to this contract?
Insurance requirements will be confirmed in April.
The RFP states that vendors need to be licensed in the 
state of North Carolina. I am licensed in other states but 
not in NC. However, as an agency owner, I have a team 
of SLPs that are licensed in NC and could provide the

services under our agency to your district (this is how we 
provide services to other districts). As long as the SLPs 
are licensed in NC, does that suffice?
Therapists must be licensed in NC and the contract 
agency must be listed on the NC Secretary of State’s 
list of registered businesses.

requirements with submission?
Insurance requirements will be confirmed in April.

company_info.text:
Transforming the lives of children, families, and communities together through our exceptional therapeutic and behavioral services.
The Stepping Stones Group is on a mission to transform lives. Together, we empower and support families and children who are seeking therapeutic and behavioral health services - whether it be in schools, at home, or in a clinic setting. We are in 42 states an 1000+ school districts, serving more than 300,000 children. With over 30 years of experience, our team consi
highlights: Hospitals and Health Care · 2,055 employees (+20.5% YoY) · Boston, United States · Founded 2014 · 28,855 followers (+35.6% this year)

The Stepping Stones Group is on a mission to transform lives. Together, we empower and support families and children who are seeking therapeutic and behavioral health services - whether it be in schools, at home, or in a clinic setting. We are in 42 states an 1000+ school districts, serving more than 300,000 children. With over 30 years of experience, our
team consists of over 11,000 highly skilled educational and behavioral health professionals dedicated to delivering high-quality therapeutic and behavioral health services.
Transforming the lives of children, families, and communities together through our exceptional therapeutic and behavioral services.

company_info.title: About - The Stepping Stones Group
company_info.text:
About - The Stepping Stones Group[Skip to content] 
[![The Stepping Stones Group]] 
## Transforming Lives Together
We are transforming the delivery of therapeutic and behavioral
health services to children with special needs and Autism.
![orange_swoosh_2] 
# On a mission to transform lives
The Stepping Stones Group grew from a simple belief: That every child is born with a special set of gifts. Throughout our history, we have partnered with over 35 mission-driven organizations that share in our
highlights:
[Explore our story ›] 
[Learn about our services ›] 
[Meet our team ›] 
## The Stepping Stones Group Mission
Transforming the lives of children, families and communities together through our exceptional therapeutic and behavioral health services.
## Our values
## Trust
Respectful and loyal in our actions
## Integrity

The Stepping Stones Group grew from a simple belief: That every child is born with a special set of gifts. Throughout our history, we have partnered with over 35 mission-driven organizations that share in our vision.

Together, we are transforming the lives of children and families, improving the quality of therapeutic and behavioral services, and joining with like-minded therapists, clinicians and educators in order to have a greater impact in our communities. Our passionate leadership team and expansive clinical support network ensure the delivery of the highest

Honest, ethical and fair in our activities
## Community
Working together to improve a child’s future
## Results
Striving to exceed expectations
## Quality
Excellence in all we do
## Inclusivity
Welcoming everyone to join in our mission
# We welcome all people

The Stepping Stones Group is committed to an inclusive workplace. As a socially conscious employer we welcome all people who have the ability and heart to join us in our mission to transform lives together. We want all employees to feel welcomed and included for their unique talents and contributions. We celebrate our differences and believe by listening,

sfusd_contract.text:
**BACKGROUND:**

This item seeks Board approval of the following items:

- the District's Annual Reports on the revised Early Literacy Support Block Grant;
- the Literacy Action Plans; and
- the revised Budget for the five grant awarded schools, Dr. Charles Drew ES, Leonard R. Flynn ES, Bret Harte ES, Paul Revere PK-8 and Sanchez ES.

The Early Literacy Support Block (ELSB) Grant is granted under California Senate Bill (SB) 98 (2020 Education Omnibus Trailer Bill) Section 113 which appropriates $50 million from the State General Fund to administer the three-year ELSB grant. Identified LEAs have the 75 schools with the highest percentage of students in grade three scoring at level 1 on the 2018 and 2019 English Language Arts (ELA) summative assessment.

The San Francisco Unified School Dist
highlights:
The San Francisco Unified School District was notified of eligibility in August 2020 and invited to submit applications for funding for five eligible schools:

- Dr. Charles Drew ES
- Leonard R. Flynn ES
- Bret Harte ES
- Paul Revere PK-8
- Sanchez ES

(4) Each local educational agency with an eligible school shall provide the State Department of Education, the school site council at each eligible school, and the governing board or body of the local educational agency with quarterly reports demonstrating that it has made expenditures consistent with the applicable literacy action plan. These reports shall

Identified LEAs have the 75 schools with the highest percentage of students in grade three scoring at level 1 on

Each LEA received a base grant of $40,000 plus $10,000 per eligible school for development of a Root Cause Analysis/Needs Assessment and a Literacy Action Plan (LAP). The California Department of Education (CDE) approved each school’s Literacy Action Plan; and they received the balance of their year one award.

TIPS, a governmental entity and a national purchasing cooperative seeks to provide a valuable and necessary solution
highlights:
TIPS, a governmental entity and a national purchasing cooperative seeks to provide a valuable and necessary solution to public entities 
and qualifying non-profits by performing the public procurement solicitation process and awarding compliant contracts to qualified

vendors. Then, where the law of a customer’s jurisdiction allows, instead of public entities and qualifying non-profits expending time, 
money, and resources on the extensive public procurement process, the use of TIPS allows public entities to quickly select and purchase

their preferred products or services from qualified, competitively evaluated vendors through cooperative purchasing.
1. Purpose. The purpose of this Agreement is to identify the terms and conditions of the relationship between TIPS and Vendor. Public

entities and qualifying non-profits that properly join or utilize TIPS (“TIPS Members”) may elect to “piggyback” off of TIPS’ 
procurements and agreements where the laws of their jurisdiction allow. TIPS Members are not contractual parties to this Agreement 
although terms and conditions of this Agreement may ensure benefits to TIPS Members.

company_info.title: WAXIE Sanitary Supply, Proudly Part of BradyPLUS
company_info.text:
WAXIE Sanitary Supply, a BradyPLUS company, has 23 Inventory Centers strategically situated in nine Western states. Each Inventory Center carries a full supply of sanitary products, janitor supplies and equipment to quickly and efficiently meet your sanitary maintenance needs.
As the true single source for all your maintenance, sanitary and janitorial requirements, you can depend on WAXIE's knowledgeable sales consultants, high-quality and effective products, equipment and procedural training, f
highlights:
WAXIE is proudly part of BradyPLUS. Offering tailored solutions for JanSan, Foodservice, and Industrial Packaging—providing SUPPLIES + SUPPORT for your daily business success.
Wholesale · 330 employees (-2.0% YoY) · San Diego, United States · 11,053 followers (+3.0% this year)

As the true single source for all your maintenance, sanitary and janitorial requirements, you can depend on WAXIE's knowledgeable sales consultants, high-quality and effective products, equipment and procedural training, friendly customer service representatives, and total inventory management to minimize costs, simplify logistics, eliminate hassles, and

Utilize WAXIE’s proven professional expertise and recommendations for your cleaning operation. Laborsaving chemicals and equipment can help control costs and maximize your labor while achieving high quality results. Professional training available including: hard floor care, carpet care, restroom care, green cleaning and more.

Our Corporate Accounts Team can leverage your volume to provide competitive pricing and lowest in-use cost, throughout your organization, regardless of geography. The industry’s leading professionals will perform a thorough survey of your business operations, and create a custom solution that supports your business goals.
maximize your satisfaction.

## About Waxie
Since 1945, WAXIE has helped campuses become cleaner, healthier, greener, and safer. WAXIE industry professionals go above and beyond industry standards to customize cleaning solutions to fit each campus, offering streamlined logistics; ongoing training

WAXIE industry professionals have gone above and beyond industry standards since 1945 to customize cleaning solutions to fit each campus, offering streamlined logistics; ongoing training and support; and delivering products and services on time and on budget.
Current Term5/18/2021 - 11/17/2025
Max Term5/17/2031
Agreement Number [#0000-4410]

Mike Gregus
Director of National Accounts
M: 858.239.8997
E: mgregus@waxie.com
[Download a copy of the contract.] 
## Products and Services offered by Waxie
### Facility Supplies

Part of Waxie’s sustainability efforts, green cleaning materials include WAXIE-Green Paper Products, WAXIE-Green Liners, WAXIE-Green Hand Soaps, WAXIE-Green Eco-Mats, WAXIE-Green Dilution Control Cleaning Chemicals, WAXIE-Green Floor Care, WAXIE-Green Carpet Care, and WAXIE-Green Ready-to-Use Cleaning Chemicals.

Supplies include Bioactive Products, Can Liners & Receptacles, Carpet Care, Chemical Dilution Control, Cleaning Without Chemicals, Deodorizing Systems, Floor Matting, Hygiene Solutions, Hard Floor Care, Tile & Grout Maintenance, Water Conservation, and WAXIE-Green Microfiber.

company_info.title: A California Tradition Since 1901
company_info.text:
[Skip to Content] 

# A California Tradition Since 1901

Crystal Creamery is California’s oldest dairy with expertise and leadership in caring for our community, environment and cows while embracing the spirit of everything the California Central Valley has to offer.

## 120 Years and Counting

We've been producing the freshest dairy for our local communities since 1901. See why our promise is as strong today as it was when our doors first opened.

We commemorated our 120th anniversary in the mo
highlights: We've been producing the freshest dairy for our local communities since 1901. See why our promise is as strong today as it was when our doors first opened.

Crystal Creamery brand dairy products have been a part of California for well over 100 years. Founded by George Knox in 1901 — and originally known as Crystal Cream & Butter — Crystal started in the back of a small grocery store in Sacramento, California. That’s where George and Caroline Knox churned butter.

## Period of Expansion
expanded its capabilities, and today, we are the largest privately owned dairy in California, producing products under the Crystal Creamery, McColl’s and Humboldt

Twenty years later in 1921, Crystal was purchased by Carl Hansen, a Danish immigrant. The Hansen family led the company for 86 years and pioneered many new technologies, growing Crystal into one of the last large independent dairy processors in the state of California. This was the beginning of the expansion of Crystal’s family of products to include milk,

In 2007, Crystal Creamery continued under the ownership of a family-owned dairy business with the purchase by Foster Dairy Farms. Foster Dairy Farms was founded in 1941 by Max and Verda Foster, and continues the tradition of nourishing families with simple, delicious ingredients and the freshest dairy from local farms. Over the years, Crystal Creamery

If commenting on a non-agenda item, speaker cards must be submitted before Public Comment is announced. The President or Chair will introduce the item and call for speaker cards.

#### Departments

[Home] » [Departments] » Business Services

Business Services

Creswell School District’s Business Services department manages CSD’s fiscal operations. As responsible stewards of district assets and resources, we provide support to our colleagues and enhance the learning environment for our students. In addition to overseeing budget, accounting, and audit functions, the business services department also manages nutrition services and custodial activities.

Loudoun County Public Schools is spending a quarter of a million dollars a year on ice cream. Taken without context, that figure may seem staggering. But not so much when you take into account the school system’s $1.28 billion fiscal year 2020 operating budget and the more than 82,000 students enrolled in the school system. The School Board approved the $250,000 renewal con
highlights: $250,000 renewal contract with Garber’s Ice Cream Company last week, among more than $12.8 million across five food supply contract renewals. The contracts needed to be approved prior to the board’s summer break for the services to be up and running for the start of school, said Becky Domokos-Bays, director of school nutrition services for the school

system—a system she’s described as “the biggest restaurant in town.” While costs are around 3-5 percent higher than last year, administrators anticipate some fluctuation in prices on certain products related to weather conditions and crop shortages during the first half of the year. company_info.title: Boys & Girls Clubs of San Francisco
company_info.text:
Boys & Girls Clubs of San Francisco is a community-based organization, offering youth ages 6-18 high-quality programs in first-class facilities. BGCSF’s skilled and caring staff expands a child’s world through inspiration, skill building, positive adult and peer relationships, and unique experiences both at the Club and outside the Club, while making every child feel heard, understood, valued, and loved.
At BGCSF, we pride ourselves on being a core institution in the San Francisco community, wit
highlights:
Our mission is to inspire and enable all young people, especially those from disadvantaged circumstances, to realize their full potential as productive, responsible, and caring citizens.
Non-profit Organizations · 115 employees (+6.8% YoY) · San Francisco, United States · Founded 1891 · 4,381 followers (+9.5% this year)

At BGCSF, we pride ourselves on being a core institution in the San Francisco community, with more than a century of youth development experience and a proven track record of helping young people become successful adults.

All staff have access to cutting-edge Learning and Development training opportunities to strengthen professional skills and create growth opportunities within the organization. We focus on youth development, leadership, and management training. Many members of our management team got their start in direct service positions or as Club kids themselves. BGCSF
places an emphasis on growing our team through those who know our organization best.

Boys & Girls Clubs of San Francisco is a community-based organization, offering youth ages 6-18 high-quality programs in first-class facilities. BGCSF’s skilled and caring staff expands a child’s world through inspiration, skill building, positive adult and peer relationships, and unique experiences both at the Club and outside the Club, while making every

company_info.title: Boys & Girls Clubs of San Francisco | Who We Are
company_info.text:
Boys & Girls Clubs of San Francisco | Who We Are
[![]] 
# Who We Are
At Boys & Girls Clubs of San Francisco, we inspire and enable all young people, especially those from disadvantaged circumstances, to realize their full potential as productive, responsible and caring citizens.
# Our Story
Since 1891, Boys & Girls Clubs of San Francisco (BGCSF) has provided high-quality, community-based youth development services to youth in San Francisco. Our mission is to inspire and enable all yo
highlights: Since 1891, Boys & Girls Clubs of San Francisco (BGCSF) has provided high-quality, community-based youth development services to youth in San Francisco. Our mission is to inspire and enable all young people, especially those from disadvantaged circumstances, to realize their full potential as productive, responsible, and caring citizens.

Our Clubs are located in neighborhoods with the fewest resources for youth, and we are open when youth need us the most—after school, on most school holidays, and all day during the summer. In addition to our 13 traditional Clubhouses and School-Based Clubs in San Francisco, we also own and operate Camp Mendocino, a 2,000-acre residential summer camp that
for a successful future.

Every day, we welcome youth between the ages of six and 18 to our thirteen[Clubhouses and School-Based Clubs]. As soon as our youth members walk through our doors, they enter an environment of stability, consistency, and physical and emotional safety. All of our Clubhouses run programs designed to be fun and engaging, while building skills and confidence

provides inspiring outdoor experiences. We impact the lives of Club members, primarily ages six to 18, by focusing on academic success, healthy lifestyles, good character and community engagement, and job readiness with earning potential.

sfusd_contract.text:
Where will 50,000 kids go during teachers strike? SFUSD and union offer half-baked plans
ADVERTISEMENT
[Skip to main content] 
Open search bar and full menu
[![The San Francisco Standard]] 
[News] # Where will 50,000 kids go during teachers strike? SFUSD and union offer half-baked plans
The teachers union suggested a list of organizations as child-care options, but most have little capacity.
![] 
Superintendent Maria Su said SFUSD will not have capacity for anywhere close to its full student population if schools close.|Source:Jeremy Chen/The Standard
Share
## Share

* [Email] 
* [Twitter(opens in new tab)] 
* [Bluesky(opens in new tab)] 
* [Facebook(opens in new tab)] 
* [LinkedIn(opens in new tab)] 
* [Telegram(opens in new tab)]

highlights: That’s the 50,000-student question facing San Francisco Unified School District Superintendent Maria Su. The Board of Education voted Tuesday to grant her special powers to maintain spaces for students or, if necessary, close the district’s roughly 120 schools in the event of a strike.
If San Francisco schools shutter for a teachers strike in the coming weeks, where will all the kids go?

The teachers union suggested a list of organizations as child-care options, but most have little capacity.
![] 
Superintendent Maria Su said SFUSD will not have capacity for anywhere close to its full student population if schools close.|Source:Jeremy Chen/The Standard
Share
## Share
* Copy linkto this article
* [Email] 
* [Twitter(opens in new tab)]

In a press conference Tuesday evening, Su said it is unlikely the district could find capacity for anywhere close to the full student population. She said the district would prioritize the roughly 7,000 special education students and those living in homeless shelters.

Partnering with industry leaders like Palo Alto Networks, they focus on safeguarding critical data through expert network analysis, design, implementation, and monitoring. A key offering is their Falco service, which continuously audits Palo Alto Networks devices to ensure secure and up-to-date configurations. peer_districts.text:
JPA Contracts | Edtech JPA[Skip to main content] 
Print
# JPA Contracts
### **How to Leverage and Renew Purchase Agreements**
### how to leverage a contract
**Shortly after your acceptance as an Associate Member you will be given login information to view documentation available only to members.**
#### **View**[**current contracts**] ****
Each vendor will have:
* A Master Agreement between the vendor and Ed Tech JPA.
* A Student Data Privacy Agreement between the vendor and Ed Tech JPA.
* A Purchase Agreement between the vendor and Members who elect to do business with that vendor.
\*This will need to be completed by the vendor and Member to establish a valid contract.|
#### **Evaluate Vendors**
Conduct your own due diligence to determine the vendor best suited for your unique needs. Score
highlights:
Obtain any necessary approvals, such as board approval, and obtain signature from an authorized signor.****
A[SAMPLE BOARD AGENDA ITEM****] isavailable[] for your convenience.
\*Thiswill need to be customized to meet the requirements of your board.
|
#### Payment Processing
Issue payment directly to the vendor.

Each vendor will have:
* A Master Agreement between the vendor and Ed Tech JPA.
* A Student Data Privacy Agreement between the vendor and Ed Tech JPA.
* A Purchase Agreement between the vendor and Members who elect to do business with that vendor.
\*This will need to be completed by the vendor and Member to establish a valid contract.|

#### Obtain a Quote and Vendor Signatures
Contact your selected vendor directly to finalize order information, and establish an implementation plan, obtain a quote and signatures on the Purchase Agreement. Attached the Quote to the Purchase Agreement as Exhibit A.
|
#### **Obtain Approvals and Internal Signatures**

All order fulfillment will be directly between vendor and purchasing Member.
|
A[CHECKLIST] is also available for your convenience.If you would like additional information about how to leverage an Ed Tech JPA agreement please view the
[Ed Tech JPA Purchasing Webinar] or view the[Ed Tech JPA How To Purchase document]

#### **Evaluate Vendors**
Conduct your own due diligence to determine the vendor best suited for your unique needs. Score each vendor, using price as the highest weighted factor.
A[**SAMPLE SCORING SHEET**] is available for your convenience. Each member is encouraged use their own internal scoring process/documents.
|

company_info.title: About Our Name – Seneca Family of Agencies
company_info.text:
#### A Note on Our Name

Seneca Family of Agencies was founded in 1985 with the mission to help children and families through the most difficult times of their lives. When our organization was established, our founders chose the name “Seneca,” inspired by their belief that the Seneca Nation of Indians cherished and nurtured its children—a value that resonated deeply with our mission. However, while this name was adopted with positive intent, it was appropriated without permission or consultation
highlights: Seneca Family of Agencies was founded in 1985 with the mission to help children and families through the most difficult times of their lives. When our organization was established, our founders chose the name “Seneca,” inspired by their belief that the Seneca Nation of Indians cherished and nurtured its children—a value that resonated deeply with our

- **Annual donations to the Seneca Nation of Indians** and to **Indigenous-led organizations and Tribes on the West Coast**, including those in California and Washington, whose communities are part of the regions we serve.
- Offering **education and training** for our staff to understand the histories, strengths, and contemporary experiences of Indigenous peoples.

Apologies, while necessary, are not enough. Our continued use of the Seneca name carries with it a responsibility — one that calls us to action, humility, and sustained commitment. As part of our effort to move from harm toward accountability and repair, we maintain the following commitments:

- Providing **culturally responsive services for the Native and Indigenous youth and families enrolled in our programs**, with the goal of offering care that is not only trauma-informed, but also respectful and honoring of Native identities, traditions, and sovereignty.

 Highline Public Schools Board Action Report 
 Supports the Strategic Plan 
DATE: 8/10/2022 
FROM: Dr. Ivan Duran, Superintendent
LEAD STAFF: Kisa Hendrickson, Chief Engagement & Partnership Officer; Valerie Allan Director of Social Services & 
Mental Health 
For Introduction: 8/17/2022 For Action:9/7/2022 
 
I.TITLE School-Based Mental Health Contract with Seneca Family of Agencies
II. WHY BOARD ACTION IS NECESSARY
Per Policy 6225, Approval of all contracts and agreements for more than $250,000 requires Board approval 
III. BACKGROUND INFORMATION 
Through a formal RFP process, for the 2021-2022 school year, Seneca Family of Agencies was awarded a $100,000 
ESSER 3 allocation to provide a 1.0 FTE school based mental health therapist who supported Des Moines Eleme
highlights:
I.TITLE School-Based Mental Health Contract with Seneca Family of Agencies
II. WHY BOARD ACTION IS NECESSARY
Per Policy 6225, Approval of all contracts and agreements for more than $250,000 requires Board approval 
III. BACKGROUND INFORMATION 
Through a formal RFP process, for the 2021-2022 school year, Seneca Family of Agencies was awarded a $100,000

increase cost of providing 2.0 FTE licensed therapists. The district is in the process of identifying and partnering with 
two additional schools.
Due to Seneca's strong grant application and success in providing school-based service staff recommends approving 
Seneca as the recipient of the $300,000 award to provide school-based mental health services.

ESSER 3 allocation to provide a 1.0 FTE school based mental health therapist who supported Des Moines Elementary 
and Southern Heights Elementary Schools. The schools were chosen due to their high need and lack of community 
based mental health resources. The partnership was highly successful in both cases and served 20+ students two

MTSS (and other student support) meetings.
Business Services facilitated a competitive RFP process for the $300,000 school-based mental health allocation
(ESSER/CARES funds). We received applications from Seneca and TrueCare. The budget of $300,000 reflects the

days per week at each school. We would like to increase the funding of this embedded model, to provide 2.0 FTE 
school-based mental health licensed therapists to serve a total of 4 schools. In addition to direct service, the funding 
allows for the assigned clinicians to become part of the school community and participate in running small groups,

# Seneca Falls Central School District – Procurement (2021M-201)

Issued Date

March 25, 2022

\[ [read complete report - pdf] \]

#### Audit Objective

Determine whether Seneca Falls Central School District (District) officials used a competitive process to procure goods and services to achieve the optimal use of District resources.

#### Key Findings

District officials did not always use a competitive process to procure goods and services to achieve the optimal use of District resources.

- 21 of 40 purchases (53 percent) we reviewed that were subject to competitive bidding and quote thresholds lacked competition or documentation to support an exception from competition. The purchases totaled $456,331 of which:
 - $331,669 was subject to competit
highlights:
#### Key Recommendations

- Document compliance with competitive purchasing requirements.
- Enter into adequate written agreements with professional service providers.

District officials generally agreed with our recommendations and indicated they plan to initiate corrective action.

Determine whether Seneca Falls Central School District (District) officials used a competitive process to procure goods and services to achieve the optimal use of District resources.

#### Key Findings

District officials did not always use a competitive process to procure goods and services to achieve the optimal use of District resources.

- District officials did not competitively procure or document an exception from soliciting competition for services provided by six professional service providers  that were paid a total of $895,668.
- The District did not have written agreements with three professional service providers paid $112,262.

- 21 of 40 purchases (53 percent) we reviewed that were subject to competitive bidding and quote thresholds lacked competition or documentation to support an exception from competition. The purchases totaled $456,331 of which:
 - $331,669 was subject to competitive bidding requirements.
 - $124,662 required quotes.

This rich tapestry of culture and ideas is sustained by our City's commitment to heighten the quality of life for San Franciscans and residents of the greater Bay Area. company_info.title: Our Work
company_info.text:
Our Work | SF.gov[Skip to main content] 
INFO PAGE
# Our Work
The Controller's Office has several critical functions that maintain Citywide systems and operations.
[Controller's Office] 
## Critical Functions in the Controller's Office
The Controller is the City’s chief financial officer. Our team includes financial, technology, analytical and other professionals who work hard to secure the City’s financial integrity and promote efficient, effective and accountable government. Som
highlights: The Controller is the City’s chief financial officer. Our team includes financial, technology, analytical and other professionals who work hard to secure the City’s financial integrity and promote efficient, effective and accountable government. Some of the Controller's Office functions exist behind the scenes. We have outlined some core duties below.

AOSD’s primary mission is to control the financial activities of the City. The division certifies contracts, pays vendors, approves personnel requisitions and reviews, monitors, controls, and projects departmental expenditures on a continuous basis to assess overall fiscal condition. The division assists departments to achieve fiscal compliance, accuracy,

### **Administration & Finance**
The Administration & Finance Division is our internal support division, serving over 300+ Controller's Office employees in two locations. The Division manages the following tasks for the Controller’s Office:
* Internal Human Resources & Hiring
* Controller's Office Payroll

timeliness and meaningfulness for the resulting financial information. The division is also responsible for producing the City's annual audited financial statements, including the Annual Comprehensive Financial Report (ACFR), the Single Audit Report, and other reports required by federal, state, and local regulations, as well as the Countywide Cost

* Controller's Office Budget
* Contracts
* Accounting and Financial Reporting

# SF Board of Education Approves Two-Year Contract Extension for Superintendent Dr. Maria Su Through June 2028
## Press Release Details
Posted Date
November 19, 2025
[Download Press Release] 
## Press Release Message
*Press Release*
**San Francisco (November 19, 2025) -**The San Francisco Board of Education on Tuesday, Nov. 18 unanimously approved a new two-year contract for Superintendent Dr. Maria Su, extending her leadership of the San Francisco Unified School District (SFUSD) through June 2028.
Dr. Su, who was appoin
highlights: **San Francisco (November 19, 2025) -**The San Francisco Board of Education on Tuesday, Nov. 18 unanimously approved a new two-year contract for Superintendent Dr. Maria Su, extending her leadership of the San Francisco Unified School District (SFUSD) through June 2028.

# SF Board of Education Approves Two-Year Contract Extension for Superintendent Dr. Maria Su Through June 2028
## Press Release Details
Posted Date
November 19, 2025
[Download Press Release] 
## Press Release Message
*Press Release*

Dr. Su, who was appointed Superintendent in October 2024, will continue to lead California’s seventh-largest school district as it advances academic excellence, fiscal stability, and equitable opportunities for all students.

“The contract for Superintendent Su reflects the Board’s commitment to continuity and stability in leadership so that we can, together, tackle the generational initiatives that enable student success,” said**Board of Education President Phil Kim**. “In order to make meaningful progress towards our goals, we must maintain focus on the strategies that improve

Dr. Su has more than 25 years of experience in public service, education, and children and family advocacy in San Francisco. As Superintendent of SFUSD, she oversees a $1.2 billion budget and nearly 9,000 employees, serving approximately 49,000 students. Her leadership emphasizes fiscal responsibility, operational

company_info.title: Who We Are - Arey Jones
company_info.text:
**Why Arey Jones for Education**

## Arey Jones has Educational Technology Solutions for Schools—Over 35 Years of K-12 Expertise

For more than 35 years, Arey Jones has been a trusted leader in educational technology, partnering with schools to create the best possible learning environments. Founded over a century ago as a small stationery and typewriter shop, we’ve evolved into one of the nation’s premier K-12 technology providers, with over 95% of our business dedicated to supporting school di
highlights: Founded in 1897 in San Diego, California, Arey Jones began as a small stationery and office supply business serving the administrative needs of local schools. In 1972, the company was acquired by Broadway Typewriter Company, owned by the Scarpella family. Under their leadership, Arey Jones evolved into Arey Jones Educational Solutions and expanded its reach

For more than 35 years, Arey Jones has been a trusted leader in educational technology, partnering with schools to create the best possible learning environments. Founded over a century ago as a small stationery and typewriter shop, we’ve evolved into one of the nation’s premier K-12 technology providers, with over 95% of our business dedicated to
nationwide.

Since the early 1990s, we have specialized exclusively in the K-12 educational market—providing hardware, software, integration, configuration, service, and support to hundreds of school districts. This singular focus gives us a unique understanding of the challenges and opportunities school districts face, and positions us as a trusted technology partner

Our mission is to help transform teaching and learning through tailored solutions that foster creativity, collaboration, innovation, and critical thinking. We understand the unique challenges schools face in today’s fast-changing technology landscape, and we work closely with each district to design and implement 21st-century learning spaces that empower

company_info.title: A Brief Arey Jones History - San Diego
company_info.text: Headquartered in San Diego, California, Arey Jones was founded in 1897 to serve the stationary and administrative needs of the local educational market. In 1972, Arey Jones was purchased by Broadway Typewriter Company, owned by the Scarpella Family. Since that time, the Scarpella Family has operated and expanded the business as Arey Jones Educational Solutions. Today, Arey Jones Educational Solutions is the premier nationwide provider of technology solutions dedicated to working exclusively wi
highlights: Solutions. Today, Arey Jones Educational Solutions is the premier nationwide provider of technology solutions dedicated to working exclusively with K-12 educational market. Arey Jones Educational Solutions has been involved with this business from the very beginning in the early 1990’s providing hardware, software, integration, configuration, service and

support. This dedication to working exclusively with the K-12 marketplace offers Arey Jones a unique qualification to meet the technology needs of Districts nationwide. Every employee within the Arey Jones company has experience working with the hundreds of School District customers around the county we have contracts with. Arey Jones has offices in

California (San Diego, Los Angeles, San Francisco), Alabama (Mobile, Baldwin), Georgia (Atlanta, Savannah), Florida (Fort Lauderdale), and North Carolina (Raleigh). The Scarpella family remains actively involved in day-to-day executive management and operations of the company, ensuring complete customer satisfaction.

highlights:
TIPS, a governmental entity and a national purchasing cooperative seeks to provide a valuable and necessary solution to public entities 
and qualifying non-profits by performing the public procurement solicitation process and awarding compliant contracts to qualified

vendors. Then, where the law of a customer’s jurisdiction allows, instead of public entities and qualifying non-profits expending time,

1. Purpose. The purpose of this Agreement is to identify the terms and conditions of the relationship between TIPS and Vendor. Public

entities and qualifying non-profits that properly join or utilize TIPS (“TIPS Members”) may elect to “piggyback” off of TIPS’ 
procurements and agreements where the laws of their jurisdiction allow. TIPS Members are not contractual parties to this Agreement 
although terms and conditions of this Agreement may ensure benefits to TIPS Members.

company_info.title: About - RAMS, Inc.
company_info.text:
What drives us to make change 
 RAMS, Inc. is a non-profit mental health organization that is committed to advocating for and providing community-based, culturally competent, and consumer-guided comprehensive services. Founded in San Francisco’s Richmond District in 1974, RAMS offers comprehensive services that aim to meet the behavioral health, social, vocational, and educational needs of the diverse community of the San Francisco Area with expertise in serving the Asian & Pacific Islan
highlights: RAMS, Inc. is a non-profit mental health organization that is committed to advocating for and providing community-based, culturally competent, and consumer-guided comprehensive services. Founded in San Francisco’s Richmond District in 1974, RAMS offers comprehensive services that aim to meet the behavioral health, social, vocational, and educational needs

Vision 
 RAMS envisions mental wellness for all people. 
 Mission 
 RAMS provides and advocates for mental health and wellness services that are centered in clients, community and culture, with expertise in serving Asian and Pacific Islander Americans. 
 
 Core Values 
 
 Inclusion
of the diverse community of the San Francisco Area with expertise in serving the Asian & Pacific Islander American and Russian-speaking populations.

We reflect our communities’ rich diversity in every aspect of our services and evolve as our communities change. 
 Impact 
 We deliver high-quality care and promising practices that result in measurable outcomes for our clients. 
 Insight

We approach our work with an understanding of the long-term impacts of trauma and a commitment to ending the stigma around mental health. 
 Integrity 
 We are principled, transparent and accountable to our clients, funders and communities. 
 Innovation

peer_districts.title: Community-Based Organizations (CBO) Contracts
peer_districts.text:
Community-Based Organization Contracts
The Fiscal Year (FY) 2025-26 Final Budget includes $969.6 million in funding for direct client services provided by 278
community-based organizations (CBOs), which is an increase of $94.8 million from FY 2024-25 and a decrease of six
contractors from 2024-25. The term CBO is defined broadly throughout this chapter to describe the direct human servic
contracts with both non-profit and for-profit service providers, as well as cities, school districts, and local hospitals.
contracts included here do not include contracts funded through the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA). 
The Final Budget includes a 5.0 percent (County General Fund) cost-of-living adjustment (COLA) for eligible CBO
contractors, totaling $8.7 million. Contracts funded in whole or part by
highlights:
contractors from 2024-25. The term CBO is defined broadly throughout this chapter to describe the direct human servic
contracts with both non-profit and for-profit service providers, as well as cities, school districts, and local hospitals.
contracts included here do not include contracts funded through the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA).

to support the increased cost.
The $82.6 million increase in Health Care Services’ CBO contracts is largely driven by increases in AC Health, Office of t
Agency Director’s service contracts. Of the $758.9 million in Health Care Services contracts, approximately $134.3 million is

million in California Work Opportunity and Responsibility to Kids (CalWORKs) services, $14.6 million for the Area Agency on
Aging, and $49.2 million for Children & Family Services. Public Assistance CBO expenditures show an increase of $8.9
million, primarily due to increases in CalWORKs and Children & Family Services contracts .

The Final Budget includes a 5.0 percent (County General Fund) cost-of-living adjustment (COLA) for eligible CBO
contractors, totaling $8.7 million. Contracts funded in whole or part by County General Fund revenue are eligible for the
COLA. Contracts funded by other sources may receive a COLA at the discretion of County agencies, if funding is available

sfusd_contract.title: Union leaders want San Francisco schools to dump ...
sfusd_contract.text:
Union leaders want San Francisco schools to dump troubled payroll software
ADVERTISEMENT
[Skip to main content] 
Open search bar and full menu
[![The San Francisco Standard]] 
[Politics] # Union leaders want San Francisco schools to dump troubled payroll software
SAP provided software to numerous California localities that later reported glitches.
![] 
San Francisco educators addressed the Board of Education during a 2022 meeting to demand cost-of-living increases and improvements to the district’s payroll system.|Source:Noah Berger for The Standard
Share

highlights:
ADVERTISEMENT
The district has spent more than[$40 million] on the system—called EMPowerSF, configured using software by SAP America—and says progress has been made. But the leader of the United Educators of San Francisco union wants the district to pull

For employees of the San Francisco Unified School District, a mundane-sounding glitch in a payroll system[that went live in January 2022] brought real-world consequences, including[canceled insurance benefits during health emergencies],[tax-filing nightmares] and delayed retirement contributions. Some school district staff even had to borrow money to pay

San Francisco’s public school staff just started their third school year with a faulty payroll system, and the district is still slogging through[a backlog of 3,000 issues(opens in new tab)].
Last month,[almost 1,000 public school employees received their paychecks days late(opens in new tab)].

San Francisco educators addressed the Board of Education during a 2022 meeting to demand cost-of-living increases and improvements to the district’s payroll system.|Source:Noah Berger for The Standard

highlights:
Approval of annual SAP Software Maintenance and Licensing Agreement
2. PURPOSE
This Board Action Report is for the review and approval of a one-year renewal of an SAP 
software maintenance and license agreement with SAP Public Services, Inc.
3. RECOMMENDED MOTION
I move the Board of Directors authorize the Superintendent to execute a one-year agreement

extension with SAP in the amount of $340,916.14 to provide enterprise and Business Systems 
Incorporated (BSI) software support from January 1, 2019 to December 31, 2019, in the form of 
a Purchase Order dated September 19, 2018 and presented to the School Board, with any minor

additions, deletions, and modifications deemed necessary by the Superintendent, and to take any 
necessary actions to implement the contract.
4. BACKGROUND INFORMATION
a. Background SAP is the system that provides functionality for the management of 
Staffing, Human Resources, Payroll, Finance, Accounting, Purchasing and Logistics at

Seattle Public Schools. It is this system that supports hiring and paying teachers and staff; 
procurement and distribution of food, furniture, equipment and supplies; and processing 
and reconciliation of all payments and incoming funds. The original license and 
maintenance agreement with SAP was entered into in January 2000. The agreement

included maintenance, SAP license grant, and Marketplace license grant (online 
procurement). Subsequently, in 2007, the SAP license and maintenance contract was 
upgraded to mySAP Business Suite license model and Human Resource payroll and 
eRecruit licenses were added. Seattle Public Schools (SPS) has been renewing the SAP 
Agreement each

**BACKGROUND:**

This item seeks Board approval of the following items:

- the District's Annual Reports on the revised Early Literacy Support Block Grant;
- the Literacy Action Plans; and
- the revised Budget for the five grant awarded schools, Dr. Charles Drew ES, Leonard R. Flynn ES, Bret Harte ES, Paul Revere PK-8 and Sanchez ES.

The Early Literacy Support Block (ELSB) Grant is granted under California Senate Bill (SB) 98 (2020 Education Omnibus Trailer Bill) Section 113 which appropriates $50 million from the State General Fund to administer the three-year ELSB grant. Identified LEAs have the 75 schools with the highest percentage of students in grade three scoring at level 1 on the 2018 and 2019 English Language Arts (ELA) summative assessment.

The Early Literacy Support Block (ELSB) Grant is granted under California Senate Bill (SB) 98 (2020 Education Omnibus Trailer Bill) Section 113 which appropriates $50 million from the State General Fund to administer the three-year ELSB grant. Identified LEAs have the 75 schools with the highest percentage of students in grade three scoring at level 1 on
the 2018 and 2019 English Language Arts (ELA) summative assessment.

Each LEA received a base grant of $40,000 plus $10,000 per eligible school for development of a Root Cause Analysis/Needs Assessment and a Literacy Action Plan (LAP). The California Department of Education (CDE) approved each school’s Literacy Action Plan; and they received the balance of their year one award.

peer_districts.title: Administrative Guidelines & Policies
peer_districts.text:
# Administrative Guidelines & Policies

[Board of Education Policies] 

## 1230.01 Development of Administrative Guidelines

The Board of Education delegates to the Superintendent the function of designing and implementing the guidelines, required actions, and detailed arrangements under which the District will operate. These administrative guidelines shall not be inconsistent with the policies adopted by the Board.

The Board itself will formulate and adopt administrative guidelines and rules only when required by law, and when the Superintendent recommends Board adoption.

The Superintendent may also issue such administrative and student handbooks as s/he may consider necessary for the effective administration of the schools and distribute them to employees and students and/or their pare
highlights: The Board of Education delegates to the Superintendent the function of designing and implementing the guidelines, required actions, and detailed arrangements under which the District will operate. These administrative guidelines shall not be inconsistent with the policies adopted by the Board.
The Board itself will formulate and adopt administrative guidelines and rules only when required by law, and when the Superintendent recommends Board adoption.

The Superintendent may also issue such administrative and student handbooks as s/he may consider necessary for the effective administration of the schools and distribute them to employees and students and/or their parents.

As long as the provisions of these administrative guidelines and handbooks are not inconsistent with Board policies, or with Federal/State law, they will be considered to be an extension of the policy manual and binding upon all employees and students.

A copy of the District's administrative guidelines manual and a copy of each handbook shall be made a part of the Board's reference materials maintained in the District office.

The Superintendent shall maintain a current organizational chart to which immediate reference can be made by the Board or any employee of the Board.

## 2210.01 Film Opt Out

company_info.title: About Us - PacificRimProduce
company_info.text:
About Us
[![]] 
![] 
# ABOUT US
# COMPANY SYNOPSIS
Pacific Rim Produce is one of the industry leaders in produce distribution. Locally owned and family operated since 1993. The company has been providing quality produce to restaurants, markets, schools, food processors, food delivery companies, and meal subscription companies. Well, known clients of ours include Lucky's, Raley's, Safeway, SaveMart, Smart & Final, and Whole Foods. Company president, John Wong has a wealth of knowled
highlights: Pacific Rim Produce is one of the industry leaders in produce distribution. Locally owned and family operated since 1993. The company has been providing quality produce to restaurants, markets, schools, food processors, food delivery companies, and meal subscription companies. Well, known clients of ours include Lucky's, Raley's, Safeway,

‍Pacific Rim Produce prides itself on serving the highest quality produce surpassing the USDA standards with strict internal quality control standards. Standards that include a Food Safety Program that is HACCP & GFSI Certified. The company offers a full line of fresh fruits and vegetables including Asian and other ethnic produce and specialty items.

The product line also includes dairy, eggs, freshly squeezed juices, pre-cuts, frozen items, oils, and tofu. Strengths consist of focusing on understanding the customer's needs, providing quick response times to our clients, on-time deliveries, and the ability to source quality produce from growers that are socially responsible. Pacific Rim

SaveMart, Smart & Final, and Whole Foods. Company president, John Wong has a wealth of knowledge and experience spanning over 30 years. Dedicated team members and an in-house chef, all have the experience to work with all varieties of businesses. From start-up restaurants to chain supermarkets, no customer is too big or small!

Produce's sustainability program includes implementing practices that are good for the custome1; environment and business growth. Pacific Rim Produce can ensure consistent product available year-round because of its direct distributor relationships with farms. Through our strong supplier partnerships, we maintain competitive pricing and assure supply

AT A GLANCE
Kat Soltanmorad, RDN, Nutrition Services Director
Truckee, CA (rural)
12 K-12 schools
4,061 students
31% eligible for free & reduced-price meals (FRPM)
235,000 lunches served (annually)
Food service model: Scratch cooking; bulk 
purchasing; waste reduction; composting; local, 
sustainable and organic farm purchasing 
Sources for organic foods: Tahoe Food Hub, Produce 
Plus and Sierra Harvest farmer donations
When Kat Soltanmorad started as Tahoe Truckee United School District’s Nutri
highlights:
Sources for organic foods: Tahoe Food Hub, Produce 
Plus and Sierra Harvest farmer donations
When Kat Soltanmorad started as Tahoe Truckee United School District’s Nutrition Services Director in 2012, 
there was already a clear desire to transform the food service program to a predominantly scratch-cooking

Kat Soltanmorad, RDN, Nutrition Services Director
Truckee, CA (rural)
12 K-12 schools
4,061 students
31% eligible for free & reduced-price meals (FRPM)
235,000 lunches served (annually)
Food service model: Scratch cooking; bulk 
purchasing; waste reduction; composting; local, 
sustainable and organic farm purchasing

model. The community also supported expanding purchases from local, sustainable and organic farms, and 
increasing bulk purchasing. Along with the backing of students and parents, Soltanmorad’s efforts to invest 
in local and organic foods has received widespread support from the district’s kitchen and facilities staff and its

The food service program’s total annual budget of about $3.5 million enables investments in quality nutritious 
foods, as well as in the food service staff who make it all possible. Providing full-time jobs with benefits has 
been a priority, demonstrating the high value the district places on its food service staff and their retention, as

leadership, including the school board, the superintendent, teachers and principals. This shared commitment 
throughout the school community for organic and healthy food access, regardless of income, has propelled 
the program and made all the difference in its success.

peer_districts.title: Security official says district's latest security move may trigger a lawsuit
peer_districts.text:
[Skip to Content] 

Categories:

- [News] 
- [PCCD] 
- [Security] 

# Security official says district’s latest security move may trigger a lawsuit

A1 Protective Services edged out in vendor consolidation

[David Rowe], Associate Editor

August 10, 2021

# ![] 

The Peralta Community College District’s (PCCD) recent decision to shift all security responsibilities to Marina Security Services was not well received by the vendor pushed out by the consolidation, A1 Protective Services.

Brajah Norris, the Director of Quality Assurance at A1, characterized the situation as “unfortunate” in an email to _The Citizen_, and went on to state that “what the board and/or administrator has done is illegal and could possibly result in legal action against the district.”

Atheria Smith, Interim Vice Chan
highlights: The Peralta Community College District’s (PCCD) recent decision to shift all security responsibilities to Marina Security Services was not well received by the vendor pushed out by the consolidation, A1 Protective Services.

In a follow-up phone call with _The Citizen_, Norris pointed out that A1 has worked with the Peralta district since 2019, initially providing security services for Berkeley City College, and then assuming expanded responsibilities when the district terminated its long standing contract with the Alameda County Sheriff’s Office (ACSO) in  2020.

PCCD initially envisioned [hiring four community-based security firms], but two of them, Community Ready Corps and Zulu Community Protection, did not hold the required licenses, as confirmed in a [May 7 email update] from interim Chancellor Jannett Jackson.  As a result, security duties for the Peralta campuses and district offices have been [divided

Brajah Norris, the Director of Quality Assurance at A1, characterized the situation as “unfortunate” in an email to _The Citizen_, and went on to state that “what the board and/or administrator has done is illegal and could possibly result in legal action against the district.”
between Marina and A1] for the past seven months.
